column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=I CLIMB THE CRAGS A SECOND TIME
#Text=I remember that I looked over the brink into the yeasty abyss with a mind hovering between perplexity and tears .
#Text=I wanted to sit down and cry -- why , I did not know , except that some great thing had happened .
#Text=My brain was quite clear as to my own position .
#Text=I was shut in this place , with no chance of escape and with no food .
#Text=In a little I must die of starvation , or go mad and throw myself after Laputa .
#Text=And yet I did not care a rush .
#Text=My nerves had been tried too greatly in the past week .
#Text=Now I was comatose , and beyond hoping or fearing .
#Text=I sat for a long time watching the light play on the fretted sheet of water and wondering where Laputa 's body had gone .
#Text=I shivered and wished he had not left me alone , for the darkness would come in time and I had no matches .
#Text=After a little I got tired of doing nothing , and went groping among the treasure chests .

#Text=One or two were full of coin -- British sovereigns , Kruger sovereigns , Napoleons , Spanish and Portuguese gold pieces , and many older coins ranging back to the Middle Ages and even to the ancients .
#Text=In one handful there was a splendid gold stater , and in another a piece of Antoninus Pius .

#Text=The treasure had been collected for many years in many places , contributions of chiefs from ancient hoards as well as the cash received from I.D.B. I untied one or two of the little bags of stones and poured the contents into my hands .
#Text=Most of the diamonds were small , such as a labourer might secrete on his person .
#Text=The larger ones -- and some were very large -- were as a rule discoloured , looking more like big cairngorms .
#Text=But one or two bags had big stones which even my inexperienced eye told me were of the purest water .
#Text=There must be some new pipe , I thought , for these could not have been stolen from any known mine .
#Text=* * *
#Text=After that I sat on the floor again and looked at the water .
#Text=It exercised a mesmeric influence on me , soothing all care .
#Text=I was quite happy to wait for death , for death had no meaning to me .
#Text=My hate and fury were both lulled into a trance , since the passive is the next stage to the overwrought .
#Text=It must have been full day outside now , for the funnel was bright with sunshine , and even the dim cave caught a reflected radiance .
#Text=As I watched the river I saw a bird flash downward , skimming the water .
#Text=It turned into the cave and fluttered among its dark recesses .
#Text=I heard its wings beating the roof as it sought wildly for an outlet .
#Text=It dashed into the spray of the cataract and escaped again into the cave .
#Text=For maybe twenty minutes it fluttered , till at last it found the way it had entered by .
#Text=With a dart it sped up the funnel of rock into light and freedom .
#Text=I had begun to watch the bird in idle lassitude , I ended in keen excitement .
#Text=The sight of it seemed to take a film from my eyes .
#Text=I realized the zest of liberty , the passion of life again .
#Text=I felt that beyond this dim underworld there was the great joyous earth , and I longed for it .
#Text=I wanted to live now .
#Text=My memory cleared , and I remembered all that had befallen me during the last few days .
#Text=I had played the chief part in the whole business , and I had won .
#Text=Laputa was dead and the treasure was mine , while Arcoll was crushing the Rising at his ease .
#Text=I had only to be free again to be famous and rich .
#Text=My hopes had returned , but with them came my fears .
#Text=What if I could not escape ?
#Text=I must perish miserably by degrees , shut in the heart of a hill , though my friends were out for rescue .
#Text=In place of my former lethargy I was now in a fever of unrest .
#Text=My first care was to explore the way I had come .
#Text=I ran down the passage to the chasm which the slab of stone had spanned .
#Text=I had been right in my guess , for the thing was gone .
#Text=Laputa was in truth a Titan , who in the article of death could break down a bridge which would have taken any three men an hour to shift .
#Text=The gorge was about seven yards wide , too far to risk a jump , and the cliff fell sheer and smooth to the imprisoned waters two hundred feet below .
#Text=There was no chance of circuiting it , for the wall was as smooth as if it had been chiselled .
#Text=The hand of man had been at work to make the sanctuary inviolable .
#Text=It occurred to me that sooner or later Arcoll would track Laputa to this place .
#Text=He would find the bloodstains in the gully , but the turnstile would be shut and he would never find the trick of it .
#Text=Nor could he have any kaffirs with him who knew the secret of the Place of the Snake .
#Text=Still if Arcoll knew I was inside he would find some way to get to me even though he had to dynamite the curtain of rock .
#Text=I shouted , but my voice seemed to be drowned in the roar of the water .
#Text=It made but a fresh chord in the wild orchestra , and I gave up hopes in that direction .
